metadata.titleEn: Data on the concentrations of persistent organic pollutants and total suspended particulate in the atmosphere at a station in Southeast Tibet (2008-2011)
metadata.description:
This data set contains data on the concentrations of persistent organic pollutants (POPs) and total suspended particulate (TSP) in the atmosphere at a station in southeastern Tibet (Lulang). The samples were collected using an atmospheric active sampler equipped with a tandem fibreglass membrane-polyurethane foam sampling head. The gaseous POPs and TSPs were collected. The sampling period for each sample was 2 weeks. The types of observed POPs include organochlorine pesticides (OCPs), polychorinated biphenyls (PCBs), and polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs). Only gaseous concentrations were detected for OCPs and PCBs, while both gaseous concentrations and particulate concentrations were detected for PAHs.
All of the data contained in the data set are measurement data. The samples were collected in the field at the Integrated Observation and Research Station of the Alpine Environment in Southeast Tibet. The sampler was an atmospheric flow active sampler equipped with a tandem fibreglass membrane-polyurethane foam sampling head, in which the fibreglass membrane was used to collect TSPs and the polyurethane foam was used to adsorb gaseous pollutants in the atmosphere. During the sampling period, the sampler was run every other day for approximately 24 hours each time, and each sample was collected for 2 weeks. The atmospheric volume collected for each sample was 500-700 cubic metres. Both gaseous and particulate POP samples were prepared and analysed in the Key Laboratory of Tibetan Environment Changes and Land Surface Processes, CAS. The sample preparation steps included Soxhlet extraction, silica-alumina column purification, removal of macromolecular impurities by a GPC column, concentration to a defined volume, etc. The analytical test instrument was a gas chromatography/ion trap mass spectrometer (Finnigan-TRACE GC/PolarisQ) produced by Thermo Fisher Scientific. The column used to separate OCPs and PCBs was a CP-Sil 8CB capillary column (50 m × 0.25 mm × 0.25 μm), and the column used to separate PAHs was a DB-5MS capillary column (60 m x 0.25 mm x 0.25 μm).

The total suspended particulate concentration in the atmosphere was determined by the gravimetric method, and the accuracy of the weighing balance was 1/100,000 g.

The field samples were subjected to strict quality control with laboratory blanks and field blanks. The detection limit of a given compound was 3 times the standard deviation of the concentration of the corresponding compound in the field blank; if the compound was not detected in the field blank, the detection limit of the method was determined by the lowest concentration of the working curve. For a sample, concentrations above the detection limit of the method are corrected by subtracting the detection limit; concentrations below the detection limit of the method but higher than 1/2 times the detection limit are corrected by subtracting half the method detection limit; and concentrations below 1/2 times the detection limit are considered undetected. The recovery rate of PAH laboratory samples was between 65-120%, and that of OCPs was between 70-130%; the sample concentrations were not corrected by the recovery rate. In the table, undetected data are marked as BDL; data marked in black italics are data corrected by subtracting 1/2 the method detection limit.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to measure concentrations of atmospheric persistent organic pollutants (POPs) and total suspended particulates (TSP) in a high-altitude environment?
Example.Answer: An example of a data collection method used to measure concentrations of atmospheric persistent organic pollutants (POPs) and total suspended particulates (TSP) in a high-altitude environment involves the use of an active air sampler equipped with a glass fiber filter and polyurethane foam tandem sampling head. This setup is used to collect gaseous pollutants and total suspended particulates over a two-week sampling period. The sampling device is operated every other day for approximately 24 hours, collecting an air volume of 500-700 cubic meters per sample. The collected samples undergo pre-treatment and instrumental analysis at a dedicated laboratory, which includes extraction, purification, and analysis using gas chromatography/ion trap mass spectrometry.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the properties and methods used for collecting atmospheric persistent organic pollutants and total suspended particulate concentrations in high-altitude environments?
Feature Specification.Answer: active air sampler, glass fiber filter-polyurethane foam tandem sampling head, two-week period, every other day, approximately 24 hours, 500-700 cubic meters, Soxhlet extraction, silica-alumina column purification, GPC column treatment, gas chromatograph/ion trap mass spectrometer, distinct chromatography columns, laboratory and field blanks, detection limits based on field blank concentrations or lowest concentration on the working curve

Quantification.Question: What is the volume of air sampled over a two-week period for atmospheric persistent organic pollutants and total suspended particulates?

Definition.Question: What is the methodology used for collecting atmospheric persistent organic pollutants (POPs) and total suspended particulates (TSP) concentrations in a high-altitude environment?
Definition.Answer: The methodology involves using an active air sampler equipped with a glass fiber filter-polyurethane foam tandem sampling head to collect gaseous pollutants and total suspended particulates. The sampling period for each sample is two weeks, with the sampler operating every other day for approximately 24 hours. Each sample collects an atmospheric volume of 500-700 cubic meters. The gaseous and particulate POPs samples undergo sample pretreatment and instrumental analysis at the Key Laboratory of Environment Change and Surface Process, Institute of Tibetan Plateau Research. Pretreatment steps include Soxhlet extraction, silica-alumina column purification, removal of macromolecular impurities using a GPC column, and concentration to a defined volume. Analysis is conducted using a gas chromatograph/ion trap mass spectrometer, with specific chromatographic columns for separating OCPs, PCBs, and PAHs.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the primary objectives behind collecting data on atmospheric persistent organic pollutants and total suspended particulates in high-altitude environments?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary objectives include understanding the concentration levels of atmospheric persistent organic pollutants (POPs) and total suspended particulates (TSP) in high-altitude environments, such as the southeastern Tibetan Plateau, to assess the impact of these pollutants on the environment and potentially human health. The collection of this data aims to provide insights into the atmospheric composition and pollution dynamics in remote and sensitive ecological regions.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the specific procedures involved in using atmospheric active samplers with glass fiber filters and polyurethane foam to collect gaseous pollutants and total suspended particulates in environmental studies?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The procedures involve using an atmospheric active sampler equipped with a tandem sampling head consisting of glass fiber filters and polyurethane foam. The glass fiber filters are used to collect total suspended particulates (TSP), while the polyurethane foam adsorbs gaseous pollutants. The sampler operates every other day for about 24 hours per session, with each sample collected over a two-week period, capturing an air volume ranging from 500 to 700 cubic meters. The collected samples are preprocessed and analyzed at a laboratory using techniques like Soxhlet extraction, silica-alumina column purification, GPC column purification, and concentration to a constant volume. The analysis is performed using a gas chromatograph/ion trap mass spectrometer, with specific chromatographic columns employed for separating different types of persistent organic pollutants (POPs).

Enablement.Question: What sampling technologies and methodologies enable the collection of atmospheric persistent organic pollutants and total suspended particulate concentrations in high-altitude environments?
Enablement.Answer: The sampling technology involves an atmospheric active sampler equipped with a glass fiber membrane-polyurethane foam tandem sampling head, which collects gaseous pollutants and total suspended particulates. The samples are collected every two weeks, with the sampler operating every other day for about 24 hours each time, collecting an air volume of 500-700 cubic meters per sample.
